reviewText:
Not bad for a visual novel.

+ It's free.
+ It's polished.
+ The artwork is both nice and original. I liked it.
+ Meaningful choices
+ A complete adventure in a space ship.
+ Varied cast of characters.
+ Interesting story and setting.
+ The protagonist is a gamer.


- Some characters are either unbelievable or plain irritating. Three of them would be booted off the ship immediately if there was even a slightly intelligent command officer on board. Some types of conduct are absolutely unacceptable on a warship during an actual war, even if a character is quirky, endearing or competent. Especially ONE character has no place in her position, and it frankly shatters my suspension of disbelief to pieces.
- The big bad is so glaringly obvious. Also, that person is so hilariously incompetent at what it does, making any attempts at spying or sabotage ridiculous. But they work... The crew is very special, you see.
- One choice in the game feels VERY contrived. It's either go stupid good or reasonably evil. Then, other characters react... in a completely unbelievable way.


Final verdict:

Despite some glaring flaws in character development, this visual novel is engaging. Sure, most of the crew's reactions are unbelievable, but it's still better than in most Hollywood films. Artwork, music, plot hovewer, make this a good and a fun experience. I recommend.

Rising Angels: Reborn is a second novel in Rising Angels series. If you wish to know more about the world and backstory you can get the first novel, Rising Angels: The Red Rose, as well as other games kind of set in same universe directly from developer's website: http://www.idhasstudios.com/?page_id=19

I played Rising Angels: Reborn before and wrote a small review back then. Republishing it here with small changes.

---------------------

I applaud to the artist who did character sprites - he or she had to work with the relatively big cast of nine characters and did a marvellous job. Each character identified by distinct silhouette using different body shapes, poses and features like ears, horns and wings. Sprites utilize poses and body language to convey information about the person, like Zuri is almost always shown in positions that imply motion or Stan often drawn covering his mouth with his hand in a gesture subconsciously associated with lying. I think wings were superfluous for character's design - they take too much screen space and people who have wings could be easily recognized without them - but it looks like each race appearances were already defined in earlier novel drawn by another artist and it's too late to change something now.

In contrast to character sprites backgrounds look nice and clean, but also grey and unimpressive and there is too few of them, but it's understandable because most of action happens on board of a small spaceship. Game could definitely use more CGs as well; few CGs present are somewhat bland and characters appear noticeably different from their usual sprites. Also, if story takes place on a spaceship, it's almost necessary to show how this ship looks from outside, but I guess nobody in development team could do mechanical design.

Music clearly was professional - it sounded like something I could hear before in some games or movie trailers. Perhaps it was licensed from some recording studio. Any sound effects are sadly missing. Adding little sound: footsteps, gunshots, woosh" of spaceship door would only help immersion.

The list of races itself is more what I expect to see in some Star Trek fanfic written by a schoolgirl

reviewText:
I rarely if ever write reviews, but I have played many VNs in my life (both Hentai and Non-H, hehe) so, upon stumbling on one that puts many +$15 visual novels to shame, I simply couldn't let this slip....


-Story 10/10

''Whom do you trust? And whom you shouldn't trust?'' This is a very mature topic in an even more mature story. So if you expect the choices to answer this question to be as Black and White as the ''Side with the Rebels against the Evil Tyrant, or side with the Evil Tyrant to crush the Rebels.'', then move along; you won't like this VN. But if you like plot full of mystery and doubt, betrayal and friendship, where one single wrong choice could end up dooming everything you care about and you like to feel the jarring tension and drama, then you'll love this work.


-Art 7/10

OK, this score is a bit viased; for a VN with so many endorphins-releasing situations, moments of sheer shock and fear.... I seriously expected more CGs of them, not just a black screen with the text. I know the most pivotal of them have CGs, but you can count those with one hand and there many, many more events that deserved a CG.
As for what Art Style and Quality over all, this VN has better art than many paid VNs; I'd give it a 10 in here.


-Sound 10/10

The BGMs tend to be quite quiet and inconspicious when nothing of importance is happening, but when something big happens.... Well, the soundtrack kicks in just in the right way (to the point you might find yourself jumping in your seat if you favor headphones). All of the music is beautiful and perdfectly crafted for whatever events are taking place, and that's simply perfect. Love the opening soundtrack, too.


-Characters 11/10

This review is viased too; I love monster girls in all their shapes (Monster Musume be praised! And Okayado-sensei's previous hentai works too, heheh) so, to have a REAL GOOD STORY, one that's not about silly romantic comedy or pointless fanservice, in a setting with monster girls on it is golden.
Going into the specifics, a good Female Protagonist (that isn't oversexualized), a Ditzy Dojikko Dragon with confidence issues, a Tsundere Ojou-sama Kitsune, a Lazy but Lovely Wolf Girl and a Cold and Harsh Elf spelled epicness to me. But, each of the characters is much, much deeper than just their physical traits; each of them feels and acts like a real living being; with virtues and faults, issues and traumas, and with unique and interesting personalities; characters you can relate to. (Such a thing is so rare these days).


-Lenght 10/10

At first I thought this was too short (beat in on 3 hours, and got the True End in just two tries) and I was about to complain about it. Then, I saw that Kickstarter page with a fully-funded sequel, and all my complains vanished and were replaced by the desire of it being released soon. If it's as epic as this one, I'll get it even if I have to pay.


So, to sum up, if you're looking for a fanservice-packed romantic comedy, with lots of bouncing bewbs, panty shots and Gainaxing, then look elsewhere (try NekoPara, which is quite good in all the aforementioned, specially the last two). But, if you are looking for an epic drama filled with emotions and anxiety, then by all means, get this VN.

Before I start my review, I have to say that I have played a number of Japanese Visual-Novels and have experience in the matter.

Rising Angels: Reborn. Is it a good visual novel? Yes.
To go into detail, I must say, the amount of detail in the dialogue is better than I expected from a free-to-play visual novel. The characters are believable. You feel that they are alive and that they mean something to you and not just some hollow arch-type character to move you along through the plot. The main story flows fluidly with the characters itself rather than the character-goes-here-for-the-plot type.

The music is decent. I mean, for a free-to-play, what do you expect? But, I do have some problems with some scenes in having the wrong kind of soundtrack to play in a heartwarming or first-clenching scenes. Other than that, it was okay.

But your main hook on this genre will not be the music, or the graphic (which is obviously CG drawn) or even the endings. Its the character development. You learn their history, their drive to their goal, their will. And you care for them across the story. With the amazing dialogue, I had no problem believing any of the hardships they went through together.

In the end, I was left feeling, Wow
date: I wasn't expecting this good of an experience." And was satisfied with how the plot ends. I cared for the characters and even for the ones that died. It managed to enter my personal territory and made me feel sad with each hardship they go through. I want them to succeed and I cheered for them. All done without paying a single penny towards the developer. (Which made me feel sour at the end for enjoying such a good experience without paying a single penny)\n\nYou don't get a massive cliffhanger that makes you want to rip your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• hair off

I was pleasantly surprised by Rising Angels: Reborn. Being used to playing original Japanese visual novels, it was refreshing to read an English VN that gave off a Western feel rather than trying to emulate the Eastern tropes and storylines that show up all the time. The characters are great, the story gets you caught up in and caring about everything that goes on.

It's a visual novel, meaning that it's meant to tell a story rather than deliver a gameplay experience, so if you're looking for a game this is not the place for you. It's short, sweet and to the point, and given it's low, low price that's more than enough.

While it may fall short of many other visual novels, Rising Angels: Reborn is one of the best original English language visual novels that i've played and i'm looking forward to what IDHAS studios comes up with in the future.

-Autosave saves.  You can go back easily to change a particular outcome if you don't want to read through the whole game again.
Cons:
-Limited replayability.  The plot is relatively set in stone, no matter the player's choice.  Some subtle changes.
-Limited roleplaying.  More of an extended comic rather than choose your adventure."  Not much choice divergence or opportunity."

reviewText:
This is not really a game, it's an interactive story.
The choices you have are very limited (didn't count but probably around 20 until reaching an ending) but can have a huge impact, especially near the end. So feel free to (quick)save if you want to explore all paths (though you can just skip to the next decision whenever you want to).
Is it worth your time? For me it was, but it certainly depends on what you like.
The focus on the game is less on action, but rather on characters and their relationships (e.g. girl-on-girl romance :D) as well as exploring the unknown and building all kinds of suspense in a sci-fi space ship environment.
The music was nice: versatile and fitting. The race concept
Don't let the supposedly cute manga/anime look fool you, the initially light-hearted story becomes actually rather mature and thrilling, because unlike most movies or series (I guess you could compare it a bit with Star Trek or Andromeda), this has multiple endings, allowing twists which can be good, bad or something inbetween and there are several dilemas that have no right" answer."

Just knowing the kind of things they've been through is what a makes a character alive. But, since we are playing as Natalie Puccile, the main character, there really isn't any of that unless the others wish to share it themselves. I'm going to try playing it again to see what other endings there are if I didn't choose what I did. I like the characters and the idea of it being in space and the unique races there are. And I did.\nSurprisingly, some of the characters weren't as annoying as I expected. There were times where I got annoyed but they didn't show up as often so there was no need to feel angry or irrate by them. I'm going to recommend this day after playing through multiple endings today.


First: The characters as just people are fun, and when not likeable are at least enjoyable as antagonists or annoyances.
Secondly: They... don't really act very strictly military. Partially, this is explained or at least commented on in-universe. Sol, this ships XO and the protagonist's friend, is constantly frustrated by his backwater no-name ship's crew and their lack of discipline. The ship itself? Small, and as you will learn, poorly equipped and outfitted. Some of the lack of professionalism in the crew can be explained by the fact that, honestly, you're serving on a ship in the dregs.


The Art is mostly good. Character sprites, at least, are good. It's a VN, so don't expect them to be too dynamic, but damn the Zuri sprites are expressive and honestly it just made me like her a ton.


Music is okay? Honestly the music is the weakest part. It's a VN, so that's not the worst sin, but a great VN has great music. It's not Juniper's Knot. The menu music is like super emo-kid Mayday Parade sounding, which personally I like but I know will make others roll their eyes.


The Story? Good. This is pretty decent sci-fi, but do NOT expect hard scifi. And that's fine. Social SF is a thing, it's totally a thing, and this is what it looks like. You are tasked with uncovering a mystery both outside your ship, in the dark of space, and... well, you'll see. The investigation requires you to make a few choices, some of which seem kind of innocent at first. The innocent choices having later ramifcations is actually really interesting and refreshing. The foreshadowing is there, which is nice, but its a bit heavy handed. Overall? It's a decent story that has a lot of potential to be expanded upon in the SEQUEL that will be coming eventually.


tl;dr: play it! It's free, it's fun, it's surprisingly good for a free game and a free Visual novel at that. You can make kissu faces at a cute dragon girl, save the universe, shoot people, and be on a crew with a space elf commander! Super fun. Godspeed.

First: The characters as just people are fun, and when not likeable are at least enjoyable as antagonists or annoyances.
Secondly: They... don't really act very strictly military. Partially, this is explained or at least commented on in-universe. Sol, this ships XO and the protagonist's friend, is constantly frustrated by his backwater no-name ship's crew and their lack of discipline. The ship itself? Small, and as you will learn, poorly equipped and outfitted. Some of the lack of professionalism in the crew can be explained by the fact that, honestly, you're serving on a ship in the dregs.


The Art is mostly good. Character sprites, at least, are good. It's a VN, so don't expect them to be too dynamic, but damn the Zuri sprites are expressive and honestly it just made me like her a ton.


Music is okay? Honestly the music is the weakest part. It's a VN, so that's not the worst sin, but a great VN has great music. It's not Juniper's Knot. The menu music is like super emo-kid Mayday Parade sounding, which personally I like but I know will make others roll their eyes.


The Story? Good. This is pretty decent sci-fi, but do NOT expect hard scifi. And that's fine. Social SF is a thing, it's totally a thing, and this is what it looks like. You are tasked with uncovering a mystery both outside your ship, in the dark of space, and... well, you'll see. The investigation requires you to make a few choices, some of which seem kind of innocent at first. The innocent choices having later ramifcations is actually really interesting and refreshing. The foreshadowing is there, which is nice, but its a bit heavy handed. Overall? It's a decent story that has a lot of potential to be expanded upon in the SEQUEL that will be coming eventually.

I would have to say that it‚Äôs a charming VN, first and foremost, and would probably deserved some of my money for all the effort and writing put into it. Mind, it isn‚Äôt enough to warrant being called a masterpiece, but I would most definitely recommend this to people looking for a good VN.

There are five endings, with only the dying ones being particularly bad (and even then, it‚Äôs on the grey; it‚Äôs a morality issue/reflection). It‚Äôs not so hard to get ‚Äò100%‚Äô or what counts for it (completing the gallery since there are no achievements, and probably seeing all the endings) since the choices are obvious but at the same time impactful; they‚Äôre not the dreary and mindless ‚Äòpick A for this ending and pick B for this ending‚Äô kind we‚Äôre sometimes saddled with and you do have to put some effort into thinking what choice would get you where you want. Mostly, though, there are many choices where it‚Äôs hard to say which was the ‚Äòright‚Äô choice - the whole thing deals with differing views of morality and who to trust.

In summary, the art is simple (not overtly beautiful, but not ugly; somewhere above passable), the music is agreeable (didn‚Äôt really stand out, but I think it did the work justice), the writing is well done (if a tad uncreative at some parts, but it is pretty well-written and gives you much to think about), and the decision points are the exact thing you want out of a Visual Novel (especially with how the decisions reflect on you as a person and your personal take on what should be done, encompassing morality, authority, loyalty, et al.).

I can say I enjoyed going through this. I‚Äôd give it a solid 7/10 overall, but about an 8/10 where it matters (for the genre).

I am recommending this game but at something like a 60-for/40-against ratio.  Ultimately, I recommend it because I paid nothing for it, and I was compelled enough by the story to finish it.  However, one should probably know that it plays more like a kinetic visual novel than a branching one that can be influenced.  Most choices either don't matter or you die when you choose the wrong one--so there is no real replay value.

Pros:
- Good artwork
- Great story! I could not predict everything.
- A good array of intriguing characters (if not fleshed out as much as I'd hoped. I really wanted to know others' personalities and motives better.)
- Happily, the script and the language is all nicely done. Few grammar/spelling/punctuation issues. (I only mention this because it's a prominent thing in a lot of VNs.)

Cons:
- A kinetic dependence on one character (Zuri) whose personality was very much a one-trick pony.  If you, like me, didn't like her from the get-go, just stop.  She's a forcibly large presence in the story. (On the upside, though, she's the only one who seemed to me to be continuously repetitive.)
- No control over much of anything. There are a few path changes that have could heavily influenced the story outcome but really don't.

It's definitely worth a play if you're looking for a good overall story! Not as much if you're looking for a VN about detailed characterization.  Thanks for offering it up on Steam :)

For those that actually have experience with visual novels, this one might not be for you. There are not a lot of choices in this VN and the choices are pretty spaced out. So unless you are looking for a visual novel that you can pretty much play just for the sake of reading and letting the story unfold without a lot of HUGE  decisions that drastically change the ending that you get, this isn't the one for you. Rising Angels: Reborn is a Visual Novel with a lot of heart and enthusiasm, but the characterization can be weak.

Overall, I did like the story, but there was more bickering than useful work being done on this ship, even between friends.  It creates tension when each crew member is different and they don't necessarily like one another.  It was hard to take seriously when conflicts played out and reminded me of childish fights with a sibling.

The ideas of the different alien cultures are good, the gradual reveal of the Dreamon culture was good.  The characters themselves don't have a lot of subtlety, though, and show their hands before the time is right in the plot.

It's odd that most of the crew are as unorganized as they are, even for rookies.  Perhaps it's that in similarly-themed series (Star Trek: TNG or Mass Effect), even the most inexperienced crew members are more organized, at least once the mission or survival is of primary importance.

It was fun to see other choices and variations on further playthroughs, as the situations you end up in are fun to see, unfortunately some choices won't change a lot of the story.

There aren't many choices for a love interest. It feels like you could have had more. The Main Character is only interested in women. Shame for anyone who may find the men interesting.

This game puts an interesting spin on doomsday cliches, but I can't help but compare because I have a lot of Visual Novel and Sci-Fi media experience.  I wish the developers the best.  If you're looking for sci-fi stories that can be challenging, this VN is maddeningly close, but not quite there.

TL;DR: This game is good in concept and execution, despite weak characterization.  Play it at least once if you love VNs, because it has something fun and unique to offer despite its flaws.
